title: R45708
content: The Energy and Water Development appropriations bill includes funding for various agencies, with a proposed budget of $38.02 billion for FY2020, which is 15% lower than the FY2019 appropriation. The bill also includes a 12% increase for DOE nuclear weapons activities. In FY2019, the total appropriations were $44.66 billion, 3% above the FY2018 level. In FY2019, the Energy and Water Development appropriations bill provided $44.66 billion, 3% above the FY2018 level. The bill was signed into law on September 21, 2018. The FY2020 budget proposes substantial reductions in DOE energy research and development programs, including cuts in fossil fuels, nuclear energy, energy efficiency, and renewable energy R&D. The FY2020 budget proposes significant reductions in DOE energy research and development programs. This includes cuts in fossil fuels, nuclear energy, energy efficiency, and renewable energy R&D. Programs targeted for elimination or phaseout include energy efficiency grants, ARPA-E, and loan guarantee programs. Funding reductions are also proposed for USACE, Reclamation, and CUP. Congressional consideration of the Energy and Water Development appropriations bill is influenced by budget enforcement measures from the Budget Control Act of 2011. The Budget Control Act of 2011 established separate limits on defense and nondefense discretionary spending for FY2012 through FY2021. Sequestration would trigger across-the-board cuts if spending limits are breached. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 increased limits for FY2018 and FY2019 but not for FY2020, resulting in lower limits. A bill to raise limits for FY2020 and FY2021 was reported by the House Budget Committee. The Budget Control Act of 2011 set limits on defense and nondefense spending, with a bill reported to raise limits for FY2020 and FY2021. The Trump Administration's budget request for FY2020 includes a significant decrease in funding for USACE, limiting new studies and construction projects. The FY2020 budget request includes a significant decrease in funding for USACE and Reclamation. The request seeks to limit funding for ongoing projects with benefits at least 2.5 times their costs. The Administration also proposes transferring the Formerly Utilized Sites Remedial Action Program from USACE to DOE. DOE's budget request includes mandatory proposals related to Power Marketing Administrations. The FY2020 budget request includes proposals to divest assets of Power Marketing Administrations (PMAs) like BPA, SWPA, and WAPA, which own transmission infrastructure. The budget projects $5.8 billion in savings over 10 years. Additionally, the budget proposes repealing WAPA's borrowing authority for its Transmission Infrastructure Program and eliminating the statutory requirement for PMAs to limit rates to cover only construction, operations, and maintenance costs. The FY2020 budget proposes divesting assets of Power Marketing Administrations (PMAs) like BPA, SWPA, and WAPA, aiming to save $5.8 billion over 10 years. It suggests transitioning PMAs to a market-based rate-setting approach, estimating $1.9 billion in new revenues over a decade. The budget also calls for repealing $3.25 billion in WAPA's borrowing authority for transmission projects, saving $640 million over 10 years. These proposals have faced opposition from various groups and Members of Congress. No legislative action has been taken on them yet. The FY2020 budget proposes terminating the DOE Weatherization Assistance Program and the State Energy Program (SEP), which provide grants for energy efficiency improvements in low-income housing and state energy programs. These programs received $257 million and $55 million respectively in FY2019, despite previous proposals for elimination in FY2018 and FY2019 budgets. The DOE's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE) oversees the SEP programs, which received $257 million for weatherization and $55 million for SEP in FY2019. The proposed elimination of grant programs is due to a shift towards early-stage R&D. The Administration's FY2020 budget request includes significant reductions in R&D funding for energy efficiency, renewable energy, nuclear energy, and fossil energy. This shift focuses DOE resources on early-stage R&D and relies more on the private sector for funding. The FY2020 DOE budget request includes significant reductions in R&D funding for energy research, focusing on early-stage R&D and relying more on the private sector for later-stage research and development. The budget also allocates new funding for a proposed nuclear waste repository at Yucca Mountain, NV, with $116 million for seeking an NRC license and developing interim nuclear waste storage capacity. The DOE requested $116 million for a nuclear waste repository at Yucca Mountain, with $38.5 million allocated to NRC for application consideration. The funding would come from two accounts: $90 million from Nuclear Waste Disposal and $26 million from Defense Nuclear Waste Disposal. Despite previous opposition and lack of funding, DOE submitted a license application in 2008, which was suspended in 2011. The FY2019 appropriations did not include funding for Yucca Mountain or the Senate's nuclear waste pilot program. The FY2020 budget request includes halting further loans and loan guarantees for DOE's loan programs, as well as rescinding unused prior-year authority and unspent appropriations. Additionally, DOE provided $3.7 billion in additional Title 17 loan guarantees for two new reactors after the budget request was submitted. The FY2020 DOE appropriation request includes $169.5 million in unspent appropriations for loan guarantee subsidy costs. $3.7 billion in additional Title 17 loan guarantees were provided for new reactors at the Vogtle nuclear plant. The request also includes $107 million for the U.S. contribution to the ITER project in France. The appropriation request is 19% below the FY2020 level and would pay for components supplied by U.S. companies for the ITER project. The FY2020 DOE appropriation request includes funding for components supplied by U.S. companies for the ITER project in France. The United States is to pay 9% of the project's construction costs, with a total estimated cost between $4.0 billion and $6.5 billion. DOE funding for the project was $122 million in FY2018 and $132 million in FY2019. The Trump Administration's FY2020 budget would eliminate ARPA-E and rescind $287 million of the agency's unobligated balances. The Trump Administration's FY2020 budget proposes to terminate ARPA-E, despite Congress increasing its funding in previous years. ARPA-E will use its unobligated balances to phase out the program by FY 2022. The FY2020 budget request for DOE Weapons Activities is 12% higher than FY2019, with a focus on nuclear warhead life-extension programs. The FY2020 budget for DOE Weapons Activities includes a 10% increase in funding for nuclear warhead life-extension programs. This includes notable increases for the W80-4 LEP and the initiation of funding for the W87-1 LEP. The budget also includes funding for the W76-2 LEP, a low-yield modification of the current W76 warhead. The FY2020 budget request includes $10 million for the W76-2 LEP, a low-yield modification of the current W76 warhead. NNSA is seeking $51.5 million for surveillance efforts for the B83 gravity bomb, with a 47% increase from FY2019. Funding for Plutonium Sustainment would increase by 97% to $712 million for FY2020 to produce plutonium pits for nuclear warheads. Sustainment funding would increase by 97% to $712 million for FY2020 to produce plutonium pits for nuclear warheads at Los Alamos National Laboratory and the Savannah River Site. The Department of Energy's Office of Environmental Management (EM) would see a decrease of $706 million (-10%) in total FY2020 appropriations request for environmental cleanup and waste management activities. The FY2020 budget request includes reductions in Cleanup (-9%), Non-Defense Environmental Cleanup (-20%), and the Uranium Enrichment Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund (-15%). There is a proposal to transfer management of the Formerly Utilized Sites Remedial Action Program (FUSRAP) from USACE to the Office of Legacy Management (LM). The FY2020 LM budget request includes $141 million for FUSRAP, down from $150 million appropriated in FY2019. USACE will continue cleanup of FUSRAP sites on a reimbursable basis. No markups had been held for FY2020 Energy and Water Development appropriations as of the report publication date. The annual Energy and Water Development appropriations bill includes four titles: Title I—Corps of Engineers—Civil; Title II—Department of the Interior (Central Utah Project and Bureau of Reclamation); Title III—Department of Energy; and Title IV—Independent Agencies. Previous appropriations and budget recommendations for FY2020 are shown in tables, with details available in separate CRS reports. USACE is an agency in the Department of Defense with military and civilian responsibilities under its civil works program. The US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) is responsible for planning, building, and operating water resources facilities funded by the Energy and Water appropriations bill. Recent omnibus water authorization acts have authorized Corps projects, including the Water Resources Reform and Development Act of 2014, the Water Resources Development Act of 2016, and the Water Resources Development Act of 2018. The Water Resources Development Acts of 2016 and 2018 authorized new US Army Corps of Engineers projects and changed various USACE policies. Unlike other infrastructure programs, federal funds for USACE projects are not distributed based on formulas or competitive grants. USACE is directly involved in planning, designing, and managing cost-shared projects with nonfederal sponsors. Prior to FY2010, Congress identified additional project funding during the appropriations process. Starting in the 112th Congress, earmarks for specific projects became subject to House and Senate approval. Since FY2010, Congress has not added funding at the project level for US Army Corps of Engineers projects. Instead, they have included "additional funding" for select categories of projects and provided direction on the use of these funds. The Bureau of Reclamation primarily built large dams and water diversion structures in the West, while the Corps of Engineers focused on flood control and navigation projects. Reclamation's original mission was to develop water supplies for irrigation in arid lands. Reclamation's mission was to develop water supplies for irrigation in arid lands in the West. Today, the agency manages hundreds of dams and diversion projects, providing water to 10 million acres of farmland and 31 million people in 17 western states. Reclamation is the largest wholesale water supplier in the region and the second-largest hydroelectric power producer in the nation. Operations of Reclamation facilities are often controversial due to their impact on fish and wildlife species and conflicts among water users during drought conditions. Reclamation's budget is mainly composed of individual project funding lines, similar to the Corps of Engineers. The agency's largest account, Water and Related Resources, covers traditional programs like construction, operations, dam safety, and ecosystem restoration. Congressional earmarks are currently restricted, limiting direct funding for specific Reclamation projects. The Central Utah Project is overseen by a separate office within the Department of the Interior. The Department of Energy (DOE) funds various programs including research on renewable energy, energy efficiency, nuclear power, fossil energy, and electricity. The Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE) focuses on transportation energy technology, energy efficiency, and renewable energy production. The Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE) conducts research on transportation energy technology, energy efficiency, and renewable energy production. EERE administers formula grants for energy efficiency improvements and state energy planning. The Sustainable Transportation program focuses on electric vehicles, vehicle efficiency, alternative fuels, and bioenergy goals. DOE's electric vehicle program aims to reduce battery costs, increase range, and decrease charge time. The vehicle fuel cell program focuses on reducing fuel cell and hydrogen fuel costs. The cost of hydrogen delivered and dispensed needs to be less than $4/gge, and the cost of a durable fuel cell system to be less than $40/kW. Bioenergy goals include developing "drop-in" fuels compatible with existing infrastructure at $3/gge. Renewable power programs aim for 3 cents per kWh for solar energy by 2030, while wind R&D focuses on cost reduction and performance improvement. The geothermal program targets an electricity generation cost of 20.8 cents/kWh by 2022. Energy efficiency programs aim to improve manufacturing processes and energy-related products, as well as R&D on lighting, space conditioning, windows, and control technologies. The advanced manufacturing program focuses on improving energy efficiency and manufacturing energy-related products. The building technologies program includes R&D on lighting, space conditioning, windows, and control technologies to reduce building energy-use intensity. The energy efficiency program provides weatherization grants for low-income housing units and state energy planning grants. The Office of Cybersecurity, Energy Security, and Emergency Response (CESER) was created from programs previously part of the Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability. The DOE Office of Electricity (OE) aims to strengthen energy infrastructure for secure and resilient energy sources. Major priorities of OE include developing a model of North American energy vulnerabilities and pursuing megawatt-scale electricity storage. The Office of Electricity (OE) leads DOE efforts to strengthen energy infrastructure for secure and resilient energy sources. Major priorities include developing a model of North American energy vulnerabilities, pursuing megawatt-scale electricity storage, and analyzing electricity policy issues. The Office also includes the DOE power marketing administrations and CESER, which focuses on energy sector-specific responses to security emergencies through R&D, guidelines, training, and emergency preparedness. DOE's Multiyear Plan for Energy Sector Cybersecurity aims to create inherently secure and resilient energy delivery systems. The Plan for Energy Sector Cybersecurity outlines DOE's strategy to strengthen energy delivery systems by addressing threats, promoting continuous improvement, and developing secure, resilient systems. It includes goals to enhance cybersecurity preparedness, coordinate incident response, and accelerate research for resilient energy systems. DOE's Office of Nuclear Energy focuses on existing nuclear fleet, advanced reactor concepts, and fuel cycle technologies to support energy independence and grid resiliency. The Reactor Concepts program area focuses on advanced reactors, including small modular reactors, to enhance sustainability and develop Generation IV reactors. Research includes advanced coolants, fuels, materials, and a Versatile Test Reactor for testing in a fast neutron environment. The program also works on extending the life of existing light water reactors beyond 60 years. The Fuel Cycle Research and Development program includes research on nuclear waste management. The Fuel Cycle Research and Development program focuses on extending the life of existing commercial light water reactors beyond 60 years. It includes research on nuclear waste management, developing technologies for separating radioactive constituents of spent fuel, accident-tolerant fuels, fuel cycle options evaluation, and preventing diversion of nuclear materials for weapons. The program is also working on developing high-assay low enriched uranium for potential use in advanced reactors. The Department of Energy's Fossil Energy R&D Program focuses on carbon capture and storage for power plants fueled by coal and natural gas. This includes research on modular coal-gasification systems, advanced turbines, solid oxide fuel cells, advanced sensors and controls, and power generation efficiency. The program also includes elements such as Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) for separating CO2, converting carbon to marketable products, and long-term geologic storage of CO2. The Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) was authorized in 1975 to provide strategic and economic security against oil supply disruptions. The program consists of caverns built within salt domes in Louisiana and Texas, serving as an emergency stockpile of crude oil. The Department of Energy has been conducting maintenance to address aging infrastructure at SPR facilities. The Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) was established in 1975 to ensure energy security and has undergone maintenance to address aging infrastructure. The SPR currently holds about 649 million barrels of oil, with various laws mandating sales of SPR oil since 2015. The legislation mandates the sale of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve over FY2017-FY2027, totaling 266 million barrels. The DOE Office of Science conducts basic research in six program areas, focusing on computing and networking capabilities for science. The DOE's Advanced Scientific Computing Research program focuses on developing computing capabilities for science, including exascale computing. Basic Energy Sciences supports research in understanding and controlling matter and energy at the atomic level, funding scientific user facilities and research centers. Basic Energy Sciences (BES) supports research in condensed matter and materials physics, chemistry, and geosciences, funding scientific user facilities and research centers. Biological and Environmental Research (BER) focuses on complex biological, climate, and environmental systems, including plant and microbial systems, climate-relevant atmospheric and ecosystem modeling. Fusion Energy Sciences (FES) aims to understand matter at high temperatures and develop fusion energy sources. The Fusion Energy Sciences program at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory supports research on high-temperature matter behavior and fusion energy development, including funding for the ITER project. Concerns have been raised about ITER's cost and schedule. The High Energy Physics program studies fundamental matter and energy constituents, while Nuclear Physics focuses on matter's basic components and interactions, including the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams project. The DOE's Loan Programs Office provides loan guarantees for energy projects, authorized by the Energy Policy Act of 2005. ARPA-E supports energy technology research projects to overcome technological barriers. The Facility for Rare Isotope Beams project is a major focus of the Nuclear Physics program at Michigan State University. The DOE's Loan Programs Office provides loan guarantees for energy projects under the Energy Policy Act of 2005. Loan guarantees cover up to 80% of construction costs for eligible projects, with successful applicants paying an upfront fee. The federal government would repay all covered loans if the borrower defaulted, reducing risk for lenders. Loan guarantee ceilings include $8.3 billion for nonnuclear technologies, $18.5 billion for nuclear power plants, $4 billion for uranium enrichment plants, and $1.18 billion for renewable energy and energy efficiency projects. In FY2007, the DOE allocated $18.5 billion for nuclear power plants, with $12.0 billion already committed. Additionally, $4 billion was set aside for loan guarantees for uranium enrichment plants, and $1.18 billion for renewable energy and energy efficiency projects under Section 1703. A total of $161 million was provided for subsidy costs for renewable energy and energy efficiency loan guarantees. The DOE also provided $8.3 billion in loan guarantees for the Vogtle plant in Georgia, with an additional $3.7 billion committed in 2019. NNSA manages the complex, with contractors operating the sites. Radiological activities are overseen by the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board. Funding elements cover material recycle, facility recapitalization, and construction projects like the Uranium Processing Facility and the Chemistry and Metallurgy Research Replacement Project. The Department of Energy's nonproliferation and national security programs, administered by NNSA's Office of Defense Nuclear Nonproliferation, support U.S. efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons worldwide. Activities include minimizing weapons-useable material stockpiles, converting reactors to low-enriched uranium, and consolidating nuclear material. For more information, refer to CRS Report R44442 and CRS Report R45306 by Amy F. Woolf and James D. Werner. The Global Materials Security program works to minimize and eliminate stockpiles of weapons-useable material worldwide through activities such as converting reactors to low-enriched uranium, consolidating nuclear material, and promoting nuclear security. It consists of three main program elements: International Nuclear Security, Radiological Security, and Nuclear Smuggling Detection and Deterrence. The Nonproliferation and Arms Control program supports U.S. objectives to prevent proliferation, ensure peaceful nuclear uses, and enable verifiable nuclear reductions. The Defense Nuclear Nonproliferation program under the Department of Energy (DOE) focuses on nonproliferation and arms control objectives, including nuclear export reviews, technology transfer authorizations, treaty obligations, and nonproliferation policies. It also includes research and development for nuclear detection and forensics technologies. Additionally, the program addresses nuclear counterterrorism and incident response through policy, planning, training, and capacity building. ARC's funding comes from fees, with a particular focus on economically distressed counties in the region.
